title: Performing social research: Bringing disability history alive for 21st century audiences
abstractText:
The purpose of this 12 month project is to facilitate collaboration between an interdisciplinary team (academics, practitioners and disabled actors) and to use innovative performance methods to transmit oral history texts of disabled people, generated by previous social scientific disability research, to secondary school children. In so doing, the work will increase disability awareness, stimulate historical understanding and build the historical agency of school-age communities in special and mainstream schools. Further it will contribute to a critical pedagogy by facilitating the development of new curriculum materials through the construction of a learning resource package (DVD and associated handbook).

Drawing on the rich knowledge of a multidisciplinary team  the project will forge connections between disciplines and methodologies to devise and facilitate 6 performance-based workshops in three secondary schools (inclusive and special).

The biographical case studies of three generations of disabled people (born in the 1940s, 1960s and 1980s) will provide the stimulus materials for these workshops and the extended Theatre-in-Education teaching package that will not only enable the longevity of the work beyond the life of the project, but also facilitate the exchange of academic knowledge to non-academic communities.
